texts.definition: Gameplay situations where players cannot themselves affect their situation.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay situations where players cannot themselves affect their situation.</style>

Games may be about putting players in positions where they can make interesting choices but sometimes games takes this away from them. By doing so, they put them in a state of <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> where even if they can notice how the gameplay progresses they are unable to do anything about it.

Player in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> can become incapacitated by falling off ledges, being pinned by infected with special powers, or by simply receiving enough damage. When this occurs players cannot by themselves affect their fate, they have to be saved by other players.

A weak example of the pattern can be found in how players can try to get out of the brig in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> - players may initiate actions to get themselves out but can only affect the success by adding one skill card while all other players can add more.

The main concern with using <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> is to consider when it should be applied and what is required for it to end. The most common reason for applying it is as a form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> might not be able to get out of by the players themselves, but can expire by itself after a certain <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limit</link></style>.

Although <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> do not in themselves create <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style>, a lack of needed <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> can do this, including a lack of <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> open up another possibility in that it allows for other players to intervene on the behalf of helpless players, as for example done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>. This can further be modulated by letting players have the possibility to request help - this is possible by default in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> but may require <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> in others. In theory help could also come from <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> but this is not a common design solution - probably because it is also difficult to regulate but without the emotional aspects of having to rely on other players. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mario%20Kart%20series">Mario Kart series</link></style> is an exception since in some <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> players that have driven their vehicles into oceans are shown being towed out of them by <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>.

Entering into <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> may be an active choice by players, e.g. <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> may be balanced so that a powerful effect requires that one becomes unable to defend oneself until the action is completed.

Adding <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> creates <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> since the helpless players will focus their attention on those players that can help them.

<style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> removes <style="Link"><link="player-agency">Player Agency</link></style>. Since it stops players from affecting the outcome of the game, it enforces <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> but with the important distinction that the gameplay progresses and that other players may still be able to act. It generally works against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empowerment">Empowerment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>. It opens up for other players to take on <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> as helpers of the player that is helpless (as well as letting the one suffering from <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> take on the role of a victim).

<style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> may not be something players perceived as a positive state, and this makes it suitable to use as <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. It can be seen as a way to create <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> which in turn quite easily creates <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in the players, and possibly <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> as they notice that effort is being made to help them or that they their fate is being sealed. It makes it impossible for players affected to have <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, but in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> players can instead be made to feel it if they can save incapacitated players, i.e. if the <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> naturally gives rise to <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> goals. When this occurs, they can contextually be seen as having <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, and saving others can easily create expectations of <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>.

For games where players can ask for help through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> may easily give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style>.

When <style="CurrentLink">Helplessness</style> is self-inflicted through engaging in <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, they provide additional <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and evoke <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations.

<style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>
